introduction.p: We quickly review the proof technique of strong induction. The basic framework is:
Base Case: Typically, you prove the statement is true for n=0 or n=1.
Inductive Step: Assume the statement is true for all k < n.
Prove True for n: Using the truth of the inductive step (for all k<n), prove that the statement is true for n.

In (weak) induction, we relate the size n case to the size n-1 case. In strong induction, we relate the size n case to the size k case for some k<n. Sometimes this is the more natural way to reduce the problem size.

statement.p:
Use strong induction to prove that all n-permutations can be decomposed into a union of disjoint cycles.
Base Case: n=1
When n=1, there is only one permutation structure: (1), which is the disjoint union of one cycle.
Inductive Step:
Assume that for k<n, every k-permutation can be decomposed into the union of disjoint cycles.
Prove True for n:
Consider any n-permutation f \in S_n. Suppose that element n has order r. This means that \[ (n, f(n) , f^2(n), \ldots, f^{r-1}(n)) \] is a cycle in the permutation n. Considering remaining n-r elements, we know that f must permute these elements among themselves. In other words, restricting f to these k=n-r elements gives a k-permutation. By strong induction, we can represent this mapping as the union of disjoint cycles. Along with the disjoint r-cycle containing n, we now have a decomposition of the original permutation f.

Prove the following identity in two different ways: \[ \sum_{k=1}^{n-1} k \cdot k! = n! - 1 \mbox{ for } n \geq 2. \]
Give a combinatorial proof of this identity.
Consider a non-identity permutation p_1p_2 \cdots p_n. Let 0 \leq j \leq n-1 be the largest integer such that p_1p_2 \cdots p_j = 12 \cdots (j-1). That is, the first j-1 elements map to themselves, but element j does not map to j. Prove that the number of such n-permutations is (n-j) \cdot (n-j)!.
Fix j where 1 \leq j \leq n. Suppose that p_1p_2 \cdots p_{j-1} = 12 \cdots (j-1), and p_{j} \neq j.
There is one way to assign p_1 p_2 \cdots p_{j-1} = 12 \cdots (j-1).
There are n-j choices for p_{j} (since we have p_{j} \neq j and the first j-1 elements have already been taken).
There are (n-j)! ways to assign the last n-j entries to the remaining n-j elements.
By the product principle, the total number of ways to create the permutation is
1 \cdot (n-j) \cdot (n-j)!
The RHS counts the number of permutations except for the identity permutation. Explain why the LHS counts the same set. (Hint: use part (a), of course!)
If p=p_1 p_2 \cdots p_n is not the identity permutation, then there is some index j such that p_j \neq j. Note that 1 \leq j \leq n-1 because the value j=n is impossible (if the first n-1 elements map to themselves, then so does the last element,
Partitioning the set of non-identity permutations according to the first such index j, we get
\sum_{j=1}^{n-1} (n-j) \cdot (n-j)! = \sum_{k=1}^{n-1} k \cdot k!
Prove the identity using (weak) induction.
Base Case: n=2
The LHS is 1 \cdot 1! = 1 and the RHS is 2!-1=1.
Inductive Step:
Assume that \sum_{k=1}^{n-2} k \cdot k! = (n-1)! - 1.
Prove True for n:
\begin{array}{rcl} \sum_{k=1}^{n-1} k \cdot k! &=& (n-1) \cdot (n-1)! + \sum_{k=1}^{n-2} k \cdot k! \\ &=& (n-1) \cdot (n-1)! + (n-1)! - 1 \mbox{ by the inductive assumption} \\ &=& n! -1. \end{array}
